 The Andhra Pradesh Reorganisation Act, 2014 (Act No. 6 of 2014) is a parliamentary enactment that:
 Provides for the reorganisation of the existing State of Andhra Pradesh by bifurcating it into two separate States-Andhra Pradesh and Telangana-and for matters connected therewith or incidental thereto.
 2. Core Legal Definitions
 A. Territorial Reorganisation (Section 3 & Schedule I)
 The territories of the existing State of Andhra Pradesh shall be divided into:
 The State of Andhra Pradesh (comprising territories specified in Part A of Schedule I), and
 The State of Telangana (comprising territories specified in Part B of Schedule I).
 B. Capital Provisions (Section 5)
 Hyderabad shall serve as the common capital for both States until such date as the newly formed State of Andhra Pradesh establishes its own capital (subject to a maximum transitional period of ten years).
 C. Asset & Liability Division (Sections 45-50)
 ll assets and liabilities of the undivided State of Andhra Pradesh shall be apportioned between the successor States based on the recommendations of the Central Government-appointed Committee and in accordance with the principles of equity, fairness, and geographical proximity.

 Any act inciting violence, hatred, or public disorder in connection with the reorganisation shall be punishable under this Act, in addition to applicable provisions of the Indian Penal Code (IPC).

 The Governor of Telangana shall have special responsibility for the security of life and property in the Hyderabad capital region during the transitional period, with powers to issue directives to the State Government.

Section 51A of the Unlawful Activities (Prevention) Act, 1967 deals with the Forfeiture of Property of a Person Involved in Unlawful Activities. It allows the Central Government to seize properties acquired through proceeds of terrorism or unlawful activities.
 Step-by-Step Procedure for Implementation
 1. Initiation of Proceedings
 The Central Government (through the National Investigation Agency (NIA) or other authorized officers) identifies a person involved in unlawful/terrorist activities under Sections 15, 17, 18, 18A, 18B, 38, or 39 of UAPA.
 A preliminary inquiry is conducted to establish a nexus between the property and unlawful activities.
 2. Issuance of Forfeiture Order (Interim)
 The Central Government issues a written order (under Section 51A(1)) declaring that the property stands forfeited to the government.
 The order must:
 Specify the reasons for forfeiture.
 Be published in the Official Gazette.
 Be served to the person affected (if known).
 3. Reference to the Competent Authority (Judicial Scrutiny)
 Within 30 days of the forfeiture order, the Central Government must refer the case to a Competent Authority (appointed under the Smugglers and Foreign Exchange Manipulators (Forfeiture of Property) Act, 1976 (SAFEMA)).
 The Competent Authority examines whether the property was:
 Illegally acquired (through terrorism/unlawful activities).
 Held benami (in someone else's name to conceal ownership).

The Criminal Law (Amendment) Act, 2018 introduced key changes to the Indian Penal Code (IPC), Indian Evidence Act, and Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC) concerning sexual offenses, particularly against women and children. Below are the essential provisions relevant for FIR generation:
 Key Amendments for FIR Purposes:
 IPC Section 376AB - Rape of a woman under 12 years of age:
 Punishment: Minimum 20 years imprisonment, extendable to life imprisonment or death.
 FIR must be filed under this section if the victim is a girl below 12.
 IPC Section 376DA - Gang rape of a woman under 16 years of age:
 Punishment: Life imprisonment or death.
 Applicable if multiple offenders are involved.
 IPC Section 376DB - Gang rape of a woman under 12 years of age:
 Punishment: Life imprisonment or death.
 FIR must mention this section if the victim is below 12 and multiple perpetrators are involved.
 IPC Section 376(3) - Rape resulting in death or persistent vegetative state:
 Punishment: Minimum 20 years to life imprisonment or death.
 FIR should include this if the victim dies or is left in a vegetative state.
 Time-bound Investigation & Trial:
 Investigation must be completed within 2 months (as per amended CrPC provisions).
 Trial should ideally conclude within 6 months.
 No Anticipatory Bail (Section 438 CrPC Barred):
 If the accused is charged under Sections 376AB, 376DA, or 376DB, anticipatory bail is not allowed.

The Code of Criminal Procedure (Amendment) Act, 2005 introduced key procedural changes in criminal investigations and trials. Below are the essential provisions relevant for FIR generation and police action:
 Key Amendments for FIR Purposes:
 Section 41A (Notice before Arrest) 
 Police must issue a notice (under Section 41A CrPC) to an accused appearing in a cognizable offense punishable with up to 7 years imprisonment.
 Arrest should be avoided if the accused complies with the notice.
 FIR must record reasons if arrest is still made.
 Section 41B (Procedure for Arrest) -
 Police must prepare a memorandum of arrest, attested by at least one witness (family member or respectable person).
 The arrested person has the right to inform a relative/friend.
 Section 50A (Obligation to Inform Arrest) -
 Police must inform a relative/friend of the arrestee about:
 The arrest,
 Custody location,
 Offense details.
 Failure to comply may affect investigation validity.
 Section 54 (Medical Examination of Arrested Person) -
 Arrested person has a right to medical examination to record injuries (if any).
 FIR must mention if medical examination was conducted.
 Section 173 (Time-bound Investigation) -
 Investigation in offenses punishable with up to 10 years must be completed within 60 days (else bail may be granted).
 Chargesheet must be filed within this period.
 Section 436A (Default Bail) -
 If trial is not completed within half the maximum sentence period, accused becomes eligible for default bail.

The CrPC, 1973 governs criminal procedure in India. Below are the key sections relevant for FIR registration, investigation, and arrest procedures that must be followed by police when filing an FIR:(A) Arrest Provisions
 Section 41 CrPC - When Arrest Can Be Made
 Police can arrest without a warrant in cognizable cases if:
 Accused committed a cognizable offense.
 There is a reasonable suspicion.
 Arrest is necessary to prevent further crime, evidence tampering, or fleeing.
 Section 41A CrPC - Notice Before Arrest (For Offenses Punishable Up to 7 Years)
 Police must issue a notice (instead of arrest) if the offense carries <=7 years imprisonment.
 Arrest only if accused fails to comply with the notice.
 Section 46 CrPC - Manner of Arrest
 No unnecessary restraint; no woman to be arrested after sunset unless exceptional (with Magistrate's written permission).
 Section 50 CrPC - Right to Know Grounds of Arrest
 Arrested person must be informed of charges immediately.
 Section 50A CrPC - Duty to Inform Relative/Friend
 Police must notify a relative/friend about the arrest.
 Section 54 CrPC - Medical Examination of Arrested Person
 Accused has a right to medical examination to record injuries (if any).
 (B) Investigation & Chargesheet Filing
 Section 156 CrPC - Police Power to Investigate
 Police can investigate without Magistrate's order in cognizable cases.
 Section 157 CrPC - Procedure for Investigation
 Police must send FIR to Magistrate and proceed to the crime scene.
 If no sufficient grounds, police can close the case with Magistrate's approval.
 Section 167 CrPC - Maximum Police Custody & Judicial Remand
 Police Custody: Max 15 days (total).
 Judicial Custody: Up to 60/90 days (depending on offense severity).
 If chargesheet is not filed within 90 days (for serious offenses), accused gets default bail (Section 167(2)) 
 Section 173 CrPC - Filing Chargesheet
 Investigation must be completed within 60-90 days (depending on offense).
 Final report (chargesheet/closure report) must be submitted to Magistrate.
 4. Victim & Witness Protection 
 Section 160 CrPC - Witness Examination
 No male below 15 years or woman shall be called to the police station (they can be examined at their residence).
 Section 161 CrPC - Recording Witness Statements
 Police must record statements accurately (can be used in trial).

The Criminal Law (Amendment) Act, 2005 introduced important changes to criminal laws in India, particularly focusing on sexual offenses, custodial crimes, and witness protection. Below are the key provisions relevant for FIR registration and police procedures:
 1. Key Amendments Relevant for FIRs
 A) Sexual Offenses (IPC Amendments)
 Section 376(2)(g) IPC (Gang Rape)
 Made punishment more stringent (minimum 10 years, extendable to life imprisonment).
 FIR must clearly mention if multiple accused involved.
 Section 376A IPC (Rape Resulting in Death/Persistent Vegetative State)
 Introduced death penalty for rape causing death or permanent vegetative state.
 FIR must include medical evidence of victim's condition.
 (B) Custodial Crimes (New Sections)
 Section 376B IPC (Sexual Intercourse by Public Servant with Woman in Custody)
 Criminalized sexual exploitation by public servants (police, jail officials, etc.).
 FIR must be registered immediately if such allegations arise.
 Section 376C IPC (Sexual Intercourse by Superintendent of Jail/Remand Home)
 Punishes sexual abuse by authority figures in custody.
 Mandatory FIR even if victim doesn't complain (suo moto action).

The Armed Forces (Special Powers) Act, 1958 (AFSPA) is an emergency legislation that grants special powers to Indian armed forces and central police forces deployed in disturbed areas to maintain public order. It provides:
 Legal Immunity to security forces for actions taken in good faith during operations.
 Extraordinary Powers, including the use of lethal force, arrest without warrant, and search without judicial authorization.
 Limited Judicial Oversight, as prosecution requires prior sanction from the Central Government.

The Border Security Force Act, 1968 is a parliamentary legislation that governs the organization, discipline, powers, and duties of the Border Security Force (BSF) - India's primary border-guarding force deployed along international borders with Pakistan and Bangladesh.
 Core Legal Provisions
 1. Constitutional Status (Section 3)
 Establishes the BSF as an armed force of the Union under the Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA).
 Personnel are subject to military-style discipline under this Act.
 2. Special Powers Granted (Section 4-5)
 Border Security Duties:
 Prevent cross-border crimes (infiltration, smuggling, trafficking).
 Detain suspects attempting illegal border crossings.
 Arrest & Search Powers (Section 5):
 Arrest without warrant if suspect violates border laws.
 Search premises/seize goods suspected of being smuggled.
 Use necessary force (including firearms) in self-defense or to prevent a felony

The Central Industrial Security Force Act, 1968 is a parliamentary legislation that governs the organization, duties, powers, and discipline of the Central Industrial Security Force (CISF) - a central armed police force responsible for providing industrial security to critical infrastructure installations across India.
 Core Legal Provisions
 1. Constitutional Status (Section 3)
 Establishes CISF as an armed force of the Union under the Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA)
 Personnel are subject to central police force discipline
 2. Special Powers Granted
 Section 4: Security duties at:
 Central Government industrial undertakings
 Critical infrastructure (airports, metro, power plants)
 Public sector undertakings
 Section 5: Powers to:
 Arrest without warrant (within protected premises)
 Search persons/vehicles entering protected areas
 Use reasonable force for security duties

The Central Reserve Police Force Act, 1949 is the primary legislation governing the organization, administration, powers and duties of India's largest central armed police force - the CRPF. This Act establishes the CRPF as a specialized armed police force under the Ministry of Home Affairs for maintaining public order and internal security.
 Core Legal Provisions
 1. Constitutional Status (Section 3)
 Creates CRPF as an armed police force of the Union
 Operates under Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA)
 Personnel subject to central police disciplinary rules
 2. Special Powers Granted
 Section 4: Authorizes deployment for:
 Riot control and crowd management
 Counter-insurgency operations
 Protection of vital installations
 Election security duties
 Section 5: Grants powers to:
 Arrest without warrant during operations
 Use reasonable force including firearms
 Search suspicious persons/vehicles
 3. Legal Immunity (Section 7)
 Protection for acts done in good faith during duty
 Requires Central Government sanction for prosecution
 Does not cover willful misuse of power

 Criminal offenses when involving:
 Fraud (IPC 420)
 Forgery (IPC 467, 468, 471)
 Criminal breach of trust (IPC 409)
 Corruption (PC Act 1988)

The Delhi, Andaman & Nicobar Islands Civil Service (DANICS) and Police Service (DANIPS) Rules, 2003 govern:
 Recruitment procedures
 Probation conditions
 Promotion criteria
 Disciplinary mechanisms
 for these All-India Services under Article 312 of the Constitution.
 Violations constitute:
 Service misconduct (Departmental action under Rule 8)
 Criminal offenses when involving:
 Forgery of service records (IPC 465/468)
 Corruption in appointments (PC Act 1988)
 Fraudulent claims (IPC 420)

The Rules of Business, 1963 constitute the procedural framework governing:
 Transaction of government business
 Allocation of administrative responsibilities
 Document routing procedures
 Decision-making protocols
 for the Puducherry UT Administration under Article 239 of the Constitution.
 Violations constitute:
 Administrative irregularities (Departmental action)
 Criminal offenses when involving:
 Official document forgery (IPC 466)
 Abuse of official position (IPC 409)
 Corruption in approvals (PC Act 1988)
